James Hupp

A content model for FEC.gov

Just enough reporting information, delivered just in time

The Federal Election Commission (FEC) administers and enforces federal campaign finance law. For every presidential or Congressional election, the FEC governs how campaigns raise, account for, and spend funds.

Background

In 2017 I joined a distributed team of designers and developers who were working with the FEC to redesign their website. When I joined, the focal points of the work were 1) switching the beta version of the new site to being the primary site; and 2) coaching the FEC’s content managers, designers, and engineers to manage the site effectively without us.

Much of the content work that had already been done focused on developing plain language content to help people understand the rules: eligibility, deadlines, definitions, etc. What had not been worked on was reporting guidance. Every candidate, party, and political action committee that engages in political activity for federal elections has reporting requirements. How do you report to the FEC properly to demonstrate that you are following the rules?

The problem

The FEC had plenty of material to support reporting: software to manage and automate filing, along with its user manual; complex scenarios designed to train multiple reporting needs at once at in-person conferences; full-scale campaign finance guides for each type of campaign committee; video walkthroughs of the software; and FAQs. For nearly every reporting task, there was some overlapping combination of examples and instruction available, each produced and managed by a different set of people.

Research showed that repetitive and disparate reporting example content meant people were never certain they had the most up-to-date information, or complete information. Siloing the content types away from each other confused users. Teams at the FEC were repeating work they didn’t need to. And keeping them separate from the help content meant it was never available as-needed in the amount needed; veteran campaigners might know it, but it was effectively hidden from people new to the field."

The work

I partnered with a senior FEC analyst to select some relatively complex examples of reporting needs (like how to report a loan from a candidate to their own campaign and then the repayment of that same loan). These served as the basis for the just-in-time reporting instructions we hoped to develop.

Our first task was to figure out how to contextualize reporting. We went through the help content together and discovered that every one of the reporting needs corresponded to existing or in-progress help content. (For example, there was already content about whether and how a candidate could make a loan to their own campaign, and what the rules were around repaying that loan.) The opportunity was clear: when someone wanted to understand the rules, that was a chance to tell them how to report their activity. They might or might not need to know right then, but they would probably notice it was there.

From there, I pulled out the relevant information for each of our chosen examples from the reporting materials. I built single narratives for each example, adding supporting media where appropriate. Bringing it together immediately let us eliminate duplicate information.

Once we had the examples written out, I extrapolated them into a rough content model that could cover most use cases cleanly. Too much fidelity would have been counter to our usual approach: collaborate, learn by buildling, and iterating until we find something that works.

I then worked through approaches with our visual designer, adjusting language and hierarchy to make sure both content and design could work within our principles and style. Once implemented, the result was a new content type in the CMS called reporting examples, presented individually on the website as How to report: [need]. And because it was its own content type, we could drop cards linking to the reporting examples into any help content where they were relevant.

Results

The reporting examples eliminated the partial overlaps of information, brought different aspects of the reporting process together out of their siloes, reduced duplication of work, and delivered the content to users right where they needed to understand it.

The final step was making this new approach viable for the content managers, who were largely analysts and communications professionals. I created a style guide for the components of the reporting example, which they were able to use to assemble dozens of reporting examples in the space of a few weeks.

The reporting example used most consistenly in this case study is Candidate personal funds loans.
